fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

fr:title.text: Homotopy category of a homotopical category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Homotopy category of a homotopical category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The homotopy category \operatorname {Ho} M of a homotopical category M with weak equivalences W is the localization of M at W. By the universal property of localization, this extends to a functor \operatorname {Ho} from homotopical categories to categories.
If a collection of morphisms W satisfies the two-of-six property, then it satisfies the two-of-three property.
If f and g are in W, then applying two-of-six to \bullet \xrightarrow {f}\bullet \xrightarrow {1}\bullet \xrightarrow {g}\bullet shows that gf is in W.
If f and gf are in W, then applying two-of-six to \bullet \xrightarrow {1}\bullet \xrightarrow {f}\bullet \xrightarrow {g}\bullet shows that g is in W.
If g and gf are in W, then applying two-of-six to \bullet \xrightarrow {f}\bullet \xrightarrow {g}\bullet \xrightarrow {1}\bullet shows that f is in W.

fr:title.text: Filtered colimits commute with finite limits in Set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Filtered colimits commute with finite limits in Set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Filtered colimits commute with finite limits in Set (and the result extends to \kappa -filtered and \kappa -small limits).
By the connection between monoids and categories, a group is a groupoid with one object.
By the monadicity theorem, the free-forgetful adjunction between Set and Grp is monadic.
The empty category is the category with no objects and no morphisms.
The trivial category is the category with one object and only its identity morphism.

fr:title.text: Projection from categories of elements creates (co)limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projection from categories of elements creates (co)limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In particular, the forgetful functor from an over category C/c strictly creates all connected limits that C admits and all colimits that C admits.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} E and C\xrightarrow {K} D be functors and suppose that the colimit \operatorname *{colim}(K\downarrow d\xrightarrow {\Pi _C} C\xrightarrow {F} E) exists for each d\in D. Then these colimits define the action on objects of the left Kan extension D\xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K F} E, and furthermore the unit of the Kan extension is determined by the colimit cone.
Dually, the limits \operatorname *{lim}(d\downarrow K\xrightarrow {\Pi _C} C\xrightarrow {F} E) define the right Kan extension \operatorname *{Ran}_K F.

By the universal property of right Kan extensions, the right Kan extension of F along 1_C is F itself. Since this diagram is preserved by all functors, we conclude that this extension is pointwise, in which case (noting that c\downarrow 1_C = c/C) it is computed by the limit formula Fc\cong \operatorname *{lim}(c/C\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xrightarrow {F} D). Now the result follows by the construction of limits from equalizers and products.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set be a presheaf for C locally small. Then F is the colimit of the diagram \text {el}(F)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C}, where y is the Yoneda embedding.

fr:title.text: Pointwise Kan extensions are computed by (co)limit formulae

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pointwise Kan extensions are computed by (co)limit formulae

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Kan extension with locally small codomains is pointwise if and only if it is computed by the (co)limit formula of the appropriate variance.

fr:title.text: Pointwise Kan extensions along fully faithful functors are isomorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pointwise Kan extensions along fully faithful functors are isomorphisms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The unit of the pointwise Kan extension of a functor F along a fully faithful functor K is an isomorphism.
The universal properties mutually imply each other by a diagam chase.

A preorder is a category P in which, for each pair of objects x and y, P(x, y) is either empty or a singleton. Explicitly, this means that it has a collection of elements (its objects) and a reflexive, transitive relation (inhabitance of hom-sets).
A category is skeletal if, whenever two objects are isomorphic, they are equal.

fr:title.text: Faithful functors reflect monos and epis

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Faithful functors reflect monos and epis

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Faithful functors reflect monomorphisms and epimorphisms.

We show the result for monos: let C\xrightarrow {F} D be faithful and Fx\xrightarrow {Ff} Fy a mono in D. Then given z\overset {g,h}{\rightrightarrows } x in C such that fg = fh, we have by functoriality that FfFg = FfFh, so since Ff is a mono, we have Fg = Fh. Now by faithfulness of F, g = h, as desired.
To conclude for epis, note that the opposite functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F^\text {op}}D^\text {op} remains faithful, so the result for monos dualizes.
Let C be a category. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: C is finitely complete;
C has a terminal object, binary products, and equalizers;
C has a terminal object and pullbacks.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first immediately implies the next two, because they refer only to the existence of certain finite limits.
The second implies the first by the same construction as the proof of the completeness criterion, noticing there that if the indexing category J is finite, then so are each of the products.
A category is finite if it has only finitely many morphisms.
Fully faithful functors reflect extant limits and colimits.

We show the result for limits. Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be fully faithful and let J\xrightarrow {K} C be a diagram in C. Further let z\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Kj be a cone over K in C whose image Fz\xrightarrow {F\lambda _j} FK is limiting in D. Let z'\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Kj be another cone. Then by the universal property of limits in D, there exists a unique map Fz'\xrightarrow {f} Fz commuting with the respective cones. Now by fully faithfulness of F, this map lifts to a unique map z'\to z commuting with the cones, witnessing the universal property of z as a limit of K.
A parallel pair is a pair of not-necessarily-equal morphisms x\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } y. An opposing pair is a pair of morphisms f: x\rightleftarrows y: g.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} E and C\xrightarrow {K} D be functors. Then a left Kan extension of F along K is a K^*-free object \operatorname *{Lan}_K F on F. Dually, a right Kan extension of F along K is a K^*-cofree object \operatorname *{Ran}_K F on F.

In other words, the universal property of a left Kan extension asks for a bijection E^C(F, GK)\cong E^D(\operatorname *{Lan}_K F, G) natural in D\xrightarrow {G} E: \operatorname *{Lan}_K F represents the functor E^D\xrightarrow {K^*} E^C\xrightarrow {\operatorname {Hom}(F, -)} Set.
A category J is filtered (\kappa -filtered) if every finite diagram (diagram with fewer than \kappa morphisms) has a cocone.
A functor is finitary if it preserves filtered colimits.

Let C\xrightarrow {K} D be a functor and E a category. Suppose that, for each C\xrightarrow {F} E, the left Kan extension D\xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K} F exists. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor E^C \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K} E^D that is left adjoint to the precomposition functor E^D \xrightarrow {K^*} E^C.
Dually, if the right Kan extensions \operatorname *{Ran}_K F all exist, this extends into a right adjoint to K^*.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition, Kan extensions are (co)free, and (co)free assignments extend uniquely to adjunctions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Monadic functors are conservative.
A monadic functor D\xrightarrow {U} C creates

fr:ol.fr:li: any colimits that C has and that T and T^2, where T is the induced monad of the adjunction, preserve.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A full subcategory D\hookrightarrow C is reflective if the inclusion admits a left adjoint, called the reflector.
The inclusion D\hookrightarrow C of a reflective subcategory is monadic.

A separator in a category C is an object s such that, for every parallel pair x\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } y in C, if fe = ge for every s\xrightarrow {e} x, then f = g. A separating family is a collection of objects s_\alpha such that, if fe = ge for every \alpha and s_\alpha \xrightarrow {e} x, then f = g.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with complete domain and locally small domain and codomain. Suppose that D has a small coseparating family and that every collection of subobjects x_\alpha \hookrightarrow x in D admits a meet, i.e. a limit. Then G has a left adjoint.

A subcategory of a category C is a collection of objects and morphisms from C closed under composition and containing all the identities. Following the pattern of subobjects, we identify a subcategory with the inclusion functor into C; in this sense, a subcategory is a faithful and injective on objects functor.
Since functors preserve equations and the property of being a split coequalizer is equationally witnessed, it is preserved by any functor.

To show the universal property of the coequalizer, let y\xrightarrow {k}w be such that kf = kg. By the equality ksh = kft = kgt = k, is this a factorization, as desired. Uniqueness follows because h is a retract, hence in particular an epi.

fr:title.text: Kleisli category embeds as free algebras

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kleisli category embeds as free algebras

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Because the Kleisli category is initial C_T and the Eilenberg-Moore category is terminal C^T in the category of resolutions, there is a unique comparison functor C_T\xrightarrow {K} C^T commuting with the adjunctions. That functor is fully faithful and its image is exactly the free algebras.

fr:title.text: Kleisli category is an initial resolution

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Kleisli category is an initial resolution

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an object c\in C_T, which is just an object in c, the compatibility condition JF_T = F requires that Jc = Fc. A map c\overset {f}{\rightsquigarrow } c' in C_T is the transpose under the adjunction F_T\dashv U_T of the underlying map c\xrightarrow {f} Tc' in C, so since the map J must commute with transposition, Jf must be the transpose of f under F\dashv U. We can compute this explicitly formula for adjoint maps: it is the map Fc\xrightarrow {Ff} FUFc'\xrightarrow {\epsilon F_{c'}} Fc'. All these choices are forced, establishing uniqueness.

An adjunction is monadic if the comparison functor to the Eilenberg-Moore category is an equivalence of categories. A functor D\xrightarrow {G} C is monadic if it is the left adjoint in a monadic adjunction; in this case D is monadic over C.

fr:title.text: Monadic categories are presented by free objects

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monadic categories are presented by free objects

fr:title.text: Eilenberg-Moore category is a terminal resolution

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Eilenberg-Moore category is a terminal resolution

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: It remains to show uniqueness. First, since U^TK = U, Kd must be an algebra TUd\xrightarrow {\gamma } Ud with carrier Ud, and furthermore must take maps d\xrightarrow {f} d' to Uf; the only issue is the identity \gamma = U\epsilon _d. By definition of a morphism of adjunctions, letting \epsilon ^T be the counit of F^T\dashv U^T, it must hold that K\epsilon = \epsilon ^TK, but by the construction of the Eilenberg-Moore category as a resolution, \gamma = (\epsilon ^TK)_d = K\epsilon _d = U\epsilon _d, as desired.
The Kleisli category C_T of a monad (T, \eta , \mu ) over a category C is the category with:

fr:ul.fr:li: objects those of C;
morphisms x\to y, written x\rightsquigarrow y the morphisms x\to Ty in C;
composition of x\overset {f}{\rightsquigarrow }y\overset {g}{\rightsquigarrow }z the composite x\xrightarrow {f}Ty\xrightarrow {Tg}T^2z\xrightarrow {\mu _z} Tz in C;
identities x\overset {1_x}{\rightsquigarrow } x the units x\xrightarrow {\eta _x} Tx of T.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: (Associativity and unitality follow from the monad laws.)

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: To show the adjunction, note that we have natural isomorphisms C_T(F_Tx, y)\cong C(x, Ty)\cong C(x, U_Ty), where the first is the definition of a Kleisli morphism and the second is the definition of U_T on objects.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Eilenberg-Moore category C^T of a monad T is the category whose objects are T-algebras and whose morphisms are algebra homomorphisms.

Let (T, \eta , \mu ) be monad on a category C. Then the category of resolutions of T \operatorname *{Adj}_T has as objects resolutions of T, and as morphisms morphisms of adjunctions whose action on C is by the identity; note that the additional compatibility condition 1_C\eta = \eta 1_C from the definition of morphism of adjunction is satisfied by construction, because both adjunctions have the same unit.

Let (T, \eta , \mu ) be a monad on a category C and x\in C an object. Then the free algebra on x is the map T^2x\xrightarrow {\mu _x} Tx. The free algebra functor C\xrightarrow {F^T} C^T from C to the Eilenberg-Moore category of T takes a map x\xrightarrow {f} y to the homomorphism Tx\xrightarrow {Tf} Tb.
An endofunctor is an endomorphic functor, i.e. a functor whose domain and codomain agree. The endofunctor category over a category C is the functor category C^C.
A monad on a category C is a monoid in the endofunctor category C^C. Explicitly, this consists of:

fr:ul.fr:li: an endofunctor C \xrightarrow {T} C;
a unit natural transformation 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } T from the identity functor;
a multiplication natural transformation T^2\xrightarrow {\mu } T.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Because the monoidal structure of the endofunctor category is strict, the monoid laws take the form of commutativity of the following diagrams of whiskered composites:
A functor is called cocontinuous if it preserves colimits.
A functor is called continuous if it preserves limits.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with locally small complete domain D. Suppose that D satisfies the solution set condition: for each object c in C, there exists a small family of maps c\xrightarrow {f_i} Gd_i in C such that any map c\xrightarrow {f} Gd factors through one of the f_i via the G-image of a map d_i\to d in D. Then G admits a left adjoint.

We prove the result for limits and conclude for colimits by duality. For any diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C, the definition of \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D) is the set of natural transformations c\to D, which by definition is the set of cones \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c). A right adjoint \operatorname *{lim}_J to this functor is thus characterized by the natural isomorphism \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c)\cong C(c, \operatorname *{lim}_J D), which is the definition of the limit. Thus pointwise the right adjoint and the limit agree, and so the right adjoint extends uniquely to the limit functor.

fr:title.text: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:title.text: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Right adjoints preserve limits. Dually, left adjoints preserve colimits.

Letting \Delta be the constant diagram functor, we have the following series of natural isomorphisms: \begin {aligned} C^J(\Delta c, GK) &\cong D^J(F\Delta c, K) &&\text {by (1)}\\\\ &\cong D^J(\Delta Fc, K) &&\text {by (2)}\\\\ &\cong D(Fc, \operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the definition of limits}\\\\ &\cong C(c, G\operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the adjunction}. \end {aligned} By definition of limits, this exhibits G\operatorname *{lim}_J K as a limit of GK.

fr:title.text: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A functor D\xrightarrow {G} C is a right adjoint if and only if, for each c\in C, the comma category c\downarrow G has an initial object. Dually, C\xrightarrow {F} D is a left adjoint if and only if, for each d\in D, the comma category F\downarrow d has a terminal object. (Here, c is the constant functor at c.)
In the forwards direction, we obtain the result since adjoint assignments are universal and universal elements are initial in exactly the specified category of elements.

In the backwards direction, let c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} Gd_0 be initial in c\downarrow G; let Fc = d_0. Initiality of \eta _c means that, for any map c\to Gd, there is a unique map Fc\to d in D making the triangle commute. In other words, \eta _c determines a bijection C(c, Gd)\cong D(Fc, d). Moreover, this bijection is natural in D, since it comes from the natural isomorphism which defines the colimit \eta _c. Thus, this data extends to an adjunction.
An adjoint equivalence is an adjunction whose unit and counit are isomorphisms; equivalently, it is an equivalence of categories whose structure isomorphisms satisfy the triangle identities.
There are composite bijections of hom-sets E(F'Fc, e)\cong D(Fc, G'E)\cong C(c, GG'e).

Let \eta and \epsilon be the unit and counits of the adjunction F\dashv G. We give a unit \eta ' and counit \epsilon ' witnessing the adjunction F_*\dashv G_*. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {H} C, the component H\xrightarrow {\eta '_H} GFH is the whiskered natural transformation \eta H. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {K} D, the component FGK\xrightarrow {\epsilon '_K} K is similarly \epsilon K.

fr:title.text: Equivalences of categories promote to adjoint equivalences

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalences of categories promote to adjoint equivalences

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F: C\leftrightarrows D G be an equivalence of categories with structure maps \eta : 1_C\cong GF and \mu : FG\cong 1_D Then there exists a map \epsilon : FG\cong 1_D so that \eta and \epsilon satisfy the triangle identities, hence witness an adjoint equivalence F\dashv G.
There is nothing special about the counit: we could instead choose a new unit to obtain the same result.

Define \gamma = G\xrightarrow {\eta G} GFG\xrightarrow {G\mu } G, which is an isomorphism because all the components are. Then define \epsilon = FG\xrightarrow {F\gamma ^{-1}} FG\xrightarrow {\mu } 1_D = FG\xrightarrow {FG\mu ^{-1}} FGFG\xrightarrow {F\eta ^{-1}G} FG\xrightarrow {\mu } 1_D, which is again an isomorphism. We need to check the triangle identities.
Let x\xrightarrow {f} x be an idempotent isomorphism. Then f = 1_x.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We have f = f1_x = fff^{-1} = ff^{-1} = 1_x.

fr:title.text: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F and F' be left adjoints to G. Then there is a unique natural isomorphism \theta : F\cong F' commuting with the units and counits of the adjunctions.
Dually, right adjoints are also unique up to unique isomorphism commuting with the units and counits.
To show uniqueness, note that \theta _c is uniquely specified as the transpose of \eta '_c across the adjunction F\dashv G, but this relationship is required for commutativity with the units to hold.

A two-variable adjunction consists of three bifunctors {C\times D\xrightarrow {F} E}, C^\text {op}\times E\xrightarrow {G} D, D^\text {op}\times E\xrightarrow {H} C and a natural isomorphism E(F(c, d), e)\cong D(d, G(c, e))\cong C(c, H(d, e)). The functor F is called biclosed, while the functors G and H are called left and right closures, respectively.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor so that, for each object d\in D, there exists a cofree object Gd\in C, i.e. an object Gd\in C together with an isomorphism {D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd)} natural in D. Then there exists a unique extension of this assignment into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C, which is then necessarily right adjoint to F.
Dually, suppose that for each d\in D, there exists a free object Fd\in C. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C which is necessarily left adjoint to F.
Let F: C\leftrightarrows D: G be a pair of opposing functors. Then the following are equivalent specifications of an adjunction:

fr:ul.fr:li: there exists a natural bijection D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd);
there exists a pair of natural transformations 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF and FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D satisfying the triangle identities;

there exists a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D so that the formula for adjoint maps induces an isomorphism (-)^\sharp = C(c, Gd)\xrightarrow {F} D(Fc, FGd)\xrightarrow {(\epsilon _d)_*} D(Fc, d).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first implies the second via the triangle identities of the unit and counit.

fr:title.text: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the forwards direction, suppose that the isomorphisms are natural, and further that the left-hand square commutes; the case in which the right-hand square commutes is similar. By the naturality of the isomorphism in C, the transpose of kf^\sharp is (Gk) f^\flat , while by naturality in D, the transpose of (Fh)g^\sharp is hg^\flat . Since the maps are equal, their transposes must also be equal; this is commutativity of the square on the right.

fr:ul.fr:li: H\eta = \eta 'H, where \eta and \eta ' are the units of the adjunctions;
K\epsilon = \epsilon 'K, where \epsilon and \epsilon ' are the counits of the adjunctions;
transposition commutes with H and K.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A pair of contravariant functors C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} D and D^\text {op}\xrightarrow {G} C are mutually left adjoint if there exists a natural isomorphism D(Fc, d)\cong C(Gd, c), and mutually right adjoint if there exists a natural isomorphism D(d, Fc)\cong C(c, Gd).

fr:title.text: Unit and counit of an adjunction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Unit and counit of an adjunction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Dually, the natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D whose component at d is the transpose of 1_{Gd} is called the counit of the adjunction.

An adjunction F\dashv G consists of a pair of opposing functors F: C\leftrightarrows D: G and a natural isomorphism D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition. We say F is left adjoint to G and G is right adjoint to F, and write

When an adjunction is fixed, two maps f\in C and g\in D are adjoint or transposes if they are connected by the adjunction. We sometimes write Fc\xrightarrow {f^\sharp } d and c\xrightarrow {f^\flat } Gd for a pair of adjoint maps.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the following limits and colimits exist. Then there is a canonical map \operatorname *{colim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F\to \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{colim}_I F.
In particular, the map goes from a colimit to a limit because colimits are easy to map out of, while limits are easy to map into.
Let J be an index category and let C be J-complete. Then there is a functor C^J \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{lim}_J} C which acts on functors by taking the limit.
Note that this theorem relies on a choice of witnesses to the completeness of C, i.e. a canonical choice of limit of each J-shaped diagram.
Let J\xrightarrow {F,G} C be naturally isomorphic diagrams. Then if their limits exist, they are isomorphic.
Taking limits is functorial and functors preserve isomorphism.
The kernel pair of a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y is the pullback of f along itself:

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the limits \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F and \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F exist. Then \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F exists, and the three limits are isomorphic.

Since representable isomorphism implies isomorphism, it suffices to prove that C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F) naturally in X. Since hom functors preserve limits, the desired result becomes \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I C(X, F); i.e., the general case reduces to that of Set. By the isomorphism I\times J\cong J\times I, it suffices to prove the first isomorphism.

The proof is essentially by currying. Let I\times J\xrightarrow {G} Set be a diagram. By the construction of limits in Set, the limit \operatorname *{lim}_J G(i, -) is the set of cones over G(i, -) with summit *, hence equivalently the set of J-tuples (x_j\in G(i, j)) satisfying G(i, f)(x_j) = x_{j'} for each j\xrightarrow {f}j'\in J. Taking the limit over I, we now conclude that \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J G consists of the tuples (x_{ij}\in G(i, j)) which commute with G-images of maps in I and J. This is exactly the data of \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} G.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
Cat is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the product category. The equalizer of functors C\overset {F,G}{\rightrightarrows } D is the subcategory of C consisting of objects x such that Fx = Gx and morphisms f such that Ff = Gf.
Cat is cocomplete.

fr:title.text: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits.
Preservation of limits follows because hom-functors preserve limits and limits in functor categories are computed pointwise.
Reflection of limits follows because the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful and fully faithful functors reflect limits.
Cat is the category of locally small categories.
A category is complete if and only if it has all small products and equalizers.
Dually, a category is cocomplete if and only if it has all small coproducts and coequalizers.
The forwards direction is immediate, because products and equalizers are limits.
In the backwards direction, let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a small diagram. Now we define maps c and d using the universal property of the product as follows:

To demonstrate the universal property of the limit, let z\xrightarrow {\mu } F be another cone over F. Then the legs of the cone yield a map z\to \prod _{j\in J} Fj by the universal property of the product. Since it is a cone, hence commutes with Ff, this map equalizes the previous diagram. We obtain the desired result by the universal property of the equalizer.
A category C is locally small if for each pair of objects x and y, the collection C(x, y) forms a set.
A category is connected if any pair of objects are connected by a zig-zag.

fr:title.text: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a small category. Then where \operatorname *{obj} C is the discrete category of objects, the forgetful functor C^A\to C^{\operatorname *{obj} A} strictly creates all limits and colimits in C. For each a\in A, the evaluation at a functor C^A\to C preserves all limits and colimits which exist in C.

Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in a locally small category C whose limit exists. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(x, \operatorname *{lim} F)\cong \operatorname *{lim} C(x, F-), where the latter is a limit in Set.
Dually, let the colimit of F exist. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} F, x)\cong \operatorname *{lim}_{J^\text {op}} C(F-, x).

Let C be locally small. The hom bifunctor preserves limits in both arguments. In particular, covariant hom-functors preserve limits and contravariant hom-functors preserve colimits, and so representable functors preserve limits.

We show the result for covariant hom-functors. Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in C with limit \operatorname *{lim} F\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Fj. The image of this diagram under C(x, -) is the diagram J\xrightarrow {F} C\xrightarrow {C(x, -)} Set, which is a limit in Set by the representability of limits.

A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D creates limits if it reflects limits and, for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C, if FK has a limit in D, then there is a limit cone of K in C whose image under F is a limit cone of FK in D.

fr:title.text: Functors which create existing limits preserve them

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Functors which create existing limits preserve them

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C\xrightarrow {F} D create a class of limits and let D have those limits. Then C has those limits and F preserves them.

Let J\xrightarrow {K} C be a diagram so that d\xrightarrow {\mu } FK is a limiting cone in D. Then since F creates limits, there is a limiting cone c\xrightarrow {\lambda } K in C so that F\lambda is a limiting cone of KF, and so since [rs-002A] \mu \cong F\lambda as cones. Now to show preservation, given any limiting cone c'\xrightarrow {\lambda '} K, it is isomorphic to \lambda and so F\lambda ' is isomorphic to F\lambda , hence is a limit cone of FK.
An endomorphism x\xrightarrow {f} x is an idempotent if ff = f.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D preserves limits if for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C and every limit cone over K, the image of this cone under F is a limit cone over FK.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D reflects limits if for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C and every cone over K whose image under F is a limit cone for FK, the original cone is a limit cone over K.
A zig-zag in a category is a finite diagram of shape \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet \dots \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet .
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
A category is cocomplete if it has all small colimits.

A cocone (or just cone) under a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with nadir c\in C is a natural transformation D\xrightarrow {\lambda } c, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism Dj\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} c, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cocone are called its colegs or just legs.
A coequalizer is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .
A colimit of a diagram is a universal cocone.

By the definition of universal elements, a colimit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{colim} D\in C and a cocone D \xrightarrow {\lambda } \operatorname *{colim} D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} D, -)\cong \operatorname *{Cocone}_D.
A category is complete if it has all small limits.

A cone over a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with apex c\in C is a natural transformation c\xrightarrow {\lambda } D, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism c\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Dj, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cone are called its legs.

Let c be an object in a category C, and let J be any category. The constant functor at c is the functor J\xrightarrow {c} C that sends every object of J to c and every morphism of J to the identity 1_c.

The constant functors induce a functor C\xrightarrow {\Delta } J^C to the functor category which sends each object of C to the corresponding constant functor and each morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y to the natural transformation with components \alpha _j = f for each j\in J.
A coproduct is a colimit of a discrete diagram. Its colegs are called coprojections.
A commutatitive diagram in a category C is a functor J\xrightarrow {D} C. The domain J is called the indexing category or the shape of the diagram.
An equalizer is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .
An initial object is a colimit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of colimits, an object i is initial in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism i\to c.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.

fr:title.text: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cones. Explicitly, let J\xrightarrow {d} C be a diagram and suppose x\xrightarrow {\lambda } D and y\xrightarrow {\mu } D are both limiting cones. Then there is a unique isomorphism x\to y commuting with the \lambda and \mu .
Dually, colimits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cocones.

This follows from the characterization of representable isomorphism, but we give a direct proof. To show isomorphism, note that the universal property of limits induces a pair of unique maps x\xtofrom [g]{f} y commuting with the cones; it remains to show these are isomorphisms. The composite gf is a map x\to x commuting with the cone \lambda , but 1_x is another such map, so by uniqueness of suchs maps gf = 1_x. The same works on the other side.
A product is a limit of a discrete diagram. Its legs are called projections.
A pullback is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \to \bullet \leftarrow \bullet .
The symbol \lrcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pullback.
Dually, pushouts preserve epimorphisms.
A pushout is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet .
The symbol \ulcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pushout.
A category is small if its collection of morphisms forms a set.
An terminal object is a limit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.

fr:title.text: Limit â€º universal property of limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limit â€º universal property of limits

fr:title.text: Colimit â€º universal property of colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Colimit â€º universal property of colimits

fr:title.text: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements \text {el}(F) has a initial object. Dually, a presheaf C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements has a terminal object.

First let c\in C represent F, so that there is a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\overset {\alpha }{\cong } F. Then the pair (c, \alpha _c(1_c)) is initial in \text {el}(F). Indeed, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), the bijection \alpha _d determines a unique element f\in C(c, d) so that Ff(\alpha _c(1_c)) = y; this exactly expresses initiality.

Conversely, let (c, x) be initial in \text {el}(F). By the Yoneda lemma, the element x\in Fc determines a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\Phi (x)} F; we need to show this is an isomorphism. Initiality of (c, x) asserts that, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), there is a unique map c\xrightarrow {f_y} d such that Ff_y(x) = y. Now in the proof of the Yoneda lemma, \Phi (x) was constructed so that F(\Phi (x)_d)(f) = Ff(x), so the assignment (d, y)\mapsto f_y inverts \Phi (x)_d.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor. The category of elements \text {el}(F) is the comma category *\downarrow F, where *\xrightarrow {*} Set is the inclusion of the point into the singleton set. Explicitly, the category of elements has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, pairs (c, x) where c\in C and x\in Fc;
as morphisms (c, x)\to (d, y), morphisms c\xrightarrow {f} d in C such that Ff(x) = y;
composition and identities inherited from C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The category of elements is further endowed with a forgetful functor \text {el}(F)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C sending (c, x) to c.
Let D\xrightarrow {F} C and E\xrightarrow {G} C be functors. Then the comma category F\downarrow G has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, triples (d\in D, e\in E, Fd\xrightarrow {f} Ge\in C);
composition by gluing along the bottom and top;
identities as in D and E.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A concrete category is a category C equipped with a forgetful functor C\xrightarrow {U} Set.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is faithful if it induces injective maps on hom-sets.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is full if it induces surjective maps on hom-sets.

fr:title.text: Full and faithfullness of the Yoneda embedding

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Full and faithfullness of the Yoneda embedding

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Yoneda embedding is full and faithful. This result is sometimes conflated with the Yoneda lemma.

Consider a natural transformation yA\xrightarrow {\alpha }yB. By the Yoneda lemma, there is a canonical morphism A\xrightarrow {f}B corresponding to \alpha , which in particular satisfies \alpha _A(1_A) = f. The natural transformation yf = f^* satisfies this condition, and so by the Yoneda lemma is the only morphism to do so. As such, the Yoneda embedding induces exactly the bijection C(A, B) = yBA \cong \hat {C}(yA, yB) established by the Yoneda lemma.
Fully faithful functors reflect isomorphisms.
Explicitly, let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a full and faithful functor. Then if x\xrightarrow {f} y in C is such that Ff is an isomorphism, then f is an isomorphism.

Let g be the inverse of Ff. Since F is full, there exists an f^{-1} in C such that Ff^{-1} = g. Now, F(f^{-1}f) = Ff^{-1}Ff = 1_{Fx} = F1_x,and the same on the other side, which completes the proof by faithfulness of F.
Fully faithful functors create isomorphisms.
Explicitly, let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a full and faithful functor. Then x\cong y in C if and only if Fx\cong Fy in D.
In the forwards direction, we already know that functors preserve isomorphisms.

Let Fx\xrightarrow {g} Fy be an isomorphism in D. Since F is full, there is a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in C such that Ff = g. Now the result follows because fully faithful functors reflect isomorphisms.
A monoid can be thought of as a category with one object, whose morphisms are the elements of the monoid and whoses composition is the operation.
For any ordinal \alpha , there is a preorder whose objects are the smaller ordinals with the usual order.
A presheaf on a category C is a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\to Set. The presheaf category \hat {C} is the functor category Set^{C^\text {op}} of presheaves on C.

A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if there exists an object c\in C and a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\cong F to the covariant hom-functor. A representation of F is a choice of such data.
Dually, a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if there exists an object c\in C and a natural isomorphism C(-, c)\cong F to the contravariant hom-functor.
Let x and y be objects in a category C. Then the following are equivalent:

fr:ul.fr:li: x and y are isomorphic;
the covariant hom-functors C(x, -) and C(y, -) are naturally isomorphic;
the contravariant hom-functors C(-, x) and C(-, y) are naturally isomorphic.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Furthermore, by the Yoneda embedding, a choice of any such isomorphism canonically determines a choice of each of the others.
This is immediate from the Yoneda lemma, since fully faithful functors create isomorphism.
We prove the covariant case. The forwards result comes from functoriality of the Yoneda embedding and the fact that functors preserve isomorphism.

In the backward direction, let \eta : C(x, -)\to C(y, -) be a natural isomorphism. Define t = \eta _x(1_x), which is a morphism y\to x, and u = \eta _y^{-1}(1_y), which is a morphism x\to y. We claim these are inverses.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and let c\in C be an object. By the Yoneda lemma, a choice of x\in Fc corresponds to a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\alpha _x} F. Such a choice expresses a universal property of c if \alpha _x is an isomorphism, and hence a representation. In this case, x is called a universal element.
The analogous dual definition applies to presheaves.

Let c and d be objects in a category C, and suppose that F and x express universal properties of both c and d. Then there is a canonical isomorphism c\cong d; in particular, a unique isomorphism that commutes with the corresponding representations.
We are thus justified in referring to "the universal object with an x."

Let C(c, -)\overset {\alpha _x}{\cong } F and C(d, -)\overset {\beta _x}{\cong } F be the corresponding natural isomorphisms given by definition of a universal property. Then their composition gives an isomorphism C(c, -)\cong C(d, -), which lifts to an isomorphism c\cong d by the Yoneda lemma.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set be a presheaf and A\in C an object. Let y be the Yoneda embedding and \hat {C} be the presheaf category. Then \hat {C}(yA, F)\cong FA, and this bijection is natural in F and A. Furthermore, the image of a natural transformation yA\xrightarrow {\alpha } F under this bijection is \alpha _A(1_A).
Dually, let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and A\in C an object. Then \operatorname {Hom}(C(A, -), F)\cong FA.
We prove the contravariant (presheaf) case. The proof is in three parts: the bijection, and the two naturality claims.
The Yoneda embedding C\xrightarrow {y}\hat {C} of C into its presheaf category is the functor with action
In other words, it is a curried version of the hom functor.
A bifunctor is a functor whose domain is a product category.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.
The category of topological spaces Top is the category whose objects are topological spaces and whose morphisms are continuous functions.
A contravariant functor between categories C and D is a functor F: C^\text {op}\to D.

Let c be an object in a category C. The contravariant hom-functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {C(-, c)} Set takes an object x to the hom-set C(x, c) and a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y to its action f^* by pre-composition:
This functor is also called the presheaf represented by c, and is written yc, y^c or h^c, the former two in reference to the Yoneda embedding.

Let c be an object in a category C. The covariant hom-functor C\xrightarrow {C(c, -)} Set takes an object x to the hom-set C(c, x) and a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y to its action f_* by post-composition:
This functor is also called the functor represented by c, and is written y_c or h_c, the first in reference to the Yoneda embedding.
The direct image functor \mathcal {P}: Set\to Set takes a set to its powerset and a map X\xrightarrow {f}Y to its action f_* by direct images, i.e. f_*(A) = \{y\in Y :\exists x\in A, f(x) = y\}.
A morphism x\xtwoheadrightarrow {f} y is an epimorphism if for any pair of parallel arrows y\overset {g,h}{\rightrightarrows } z, gf = hf implies g = h.

A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is an equivalence of categories if there exists a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C together with natural isomorphisms FG\cong 1_D and GF\cong 1_C. Two categories are equivalent if there exists an equivalence of categories between them, in which case we write C\simeq D .
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C and D be categories. The functor category D^C has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, functors C\to D;
as morphisms, natural transformations;
as composition, vertical composition;
as identities, the identity natural transformations.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Functors preserve isomorphisms.
Explicitly, let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor. If x\xrightarrow {f} y is an isomorphism in C, then Ff is an isomorphism in D.
The inverse is Ff^{-1}. We have (Ff^{-1})(Ff) = F(f^{-1}f) = F(1_x) = 1_{F(x)}, and the same works on the other side.

Let C be a category. The hom bifunctor C^\text {op}\times C\xrightarrow {C(-, -)} Set takes objects x and y to the hom-set C(x, y), and morphisms x\xleftarrow {f} y and z\xrightarrow {g} w to their action by pre- and post-composition f^*g_*, i.e.

Let C\xrightarrow {F,F'}D and D\xrightarrow {G,G'}E be functors with F\xrightarrow {\alpha } F' and G\xrightarrow {\beta } G' natural transformations. Then their horizontal composite GF\xrightarrow {\beta *\alpha } G'F' is a natural transformation with components given by the following commutative square:
Diagramatically:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzcd}[baseline=(current bounding box.center)] C\ar [rr, "F", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "F'"', bend right=50] & \Downarrow \alpha & D\ar [rr, "G", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "G'"', bend right=50] & \Downarrow \beta & E & \rightsquigarrow & C \ar [rr, "GF", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "G'F'"', bend right=50] & \Downarrow \beta *\alpha & E\makebox [0pt][l]{.} \\ \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor. The identity natural transformation F\xrightarrow {1_F} F is the natural transformation with components (1_F)_c = 1_{Fc}.
The inverse image functor \mathcal {P}: Set^\text {op}\to Set takes a set to its powerset and a map X\xrightarrow {f}Y to its action f^{-1} by inverse images, i.e. f_*(A) = \{x\in X: f(x)\in A\}.
A morphism x\xhookrightarrow {f} y is a monomorphism if for any pair of parallel arrows z\overset {g,h}{\rightrightarrows } x, fg = fh implies g = h.

A natural transformation F\xrightarrow {\alpha } G between functors C\xrightarrow {F,G} D consists of, for every object x\in C, a morphism \alpha _x: Fx\to Gx (the components) such that, for every morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y in C, the following diagram commutes:
A natural isomorphism is an isomorphism in a functor category. Explicitly, it is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.
The product category is the product in Cat. Explicitly, let C and D be categories. The product category C\times D has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, pairs (x, y) of objects in C and D, respectively;
as morphisms (x, y)\to (x', y'), pairs (f, g) of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} x' and y\xrightarrow {g} y';
composition and identities defined componentwise.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism y\xrightarrow {r}x is a retraction, post-inverse, or split epimorphism if there exists a morphism x\xrightarrow {s}y such that rs = 1_x.
A morphism x\xrightarrow {s}y is a section, pre-inverse, or split monomorphism if there exists a morphism y\xrightarrow {r}x such that rs = 1_x.

Let F\xrightarrow {\alpha } G and G\xrightarrow {\beta } H be natural transformations with components \alpha _x and \beta _x, respectively. Then their vertical composite F\xrightarrow {\beta \alpha } H is the natural transformation with components (\beta \alpha )_x = \beta _x\alpha _x. Diagramatically:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzcd}[baseline=(current bounding box.center)] & \Downarrow \alpha \\[-2.1em] C\ar [rr, "F", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "G", near start]\ar [rr, "H"', bend right=50] && D & \rightsquigarrow & C \ar [rr, "F", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "H"', bend right=50] & \Downarrow \beta \alpha & D\makebox [0pt][l]{.} \\[-2.1em] & \Downarrow \beta \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism is an automorphism if it is both an endomorphism and an isomorphism.
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
Let C be a category and c be an object. Then the coslice category or under category c/C is:

fr:ul.fr:li: the category of elements of the covariant hom-functor C(c, -);
the comma category (c\downarrow 1_C), where *\xrightarrow {c} C is the inclusion of the point.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Explicitly, it has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, morphisms c\xrightarrow {f} x in C;
as composition, pasting along the shared morphism;
as identities, the unit laws in C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A morphism in a category is an endomorphism if its domain and codomain agree.
Let x\xrightarrow {f}y be an isomorphism with inverses g and h. Then g = h.
We have g = g1_y = gfh = 1_xh = h.
A morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in a category is an isomorphism if there exists an inverse morphism y\xrightarrow {f^{-1}}x such that f^{-1}f = 1_x and ff^{-1} = 1_y, i.e.
and
commute. If there exists an isomorphism between x and y, we say they are isomorphic and write x\cong y.
Let C be a category. The opposite category C^{\text {op}} has:

fr:ul.fr:li: the same objects as in C;
for each morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in C, a morphism y\xrightarrow {f^{\text {op}}} x;
composition and identities as in C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C be a category and c be an object. Then the slice category or over category C/c is:

fr:ul.fr:li: the category of elements of the contravariant hom-functor C(-, c);
the comma category (1_C\downarrow c), where *\xrightarrow {c} C is the inclusion of the point.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Explicitly it has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} c in C;
as composition, pasting along the shared morphism;
as identities, the unit laws in C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A commutatitive diagram in a category C is a functor J\xrightarrow {D} C. The domain J is called the indexing category or the shape of the diagram.

A cone over a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with apex c\in C is a natural transformation c\xrightarrow {\lambda } D, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism c\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Dj, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cone are called its legs.
A limit of a diagram is a universal cone.

By the definition of universal elements, a limit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{lim} D\in C and a cone \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(-, \operatorname *{lim} D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D.
Dually:
A colimit of a diagram is a universal cocone.

By the definition of universal elements, a colimit of a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C consists of an object \operatorname *{colim} D\in C and a cocone D \xrightarrow {\lambda } \operatorname *{colim} D which is universal in the sense that it induces, by the Yoneda lemma, a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} D, -)\cong \operatorname *{Cocone}_D.

fr:title.text: Map out of colimits, map into limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Map out of colimits, map into limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The universal property of limits makes it easy to construct morphisms into them; the universal property of colimits makes it easy to construct maps out of them.
A product is a limit of a discrete diagram. Its legs are called projections.
A coproduct is a colimit of a discrete diagram. Its colegs are called coprojections.
A pullback is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \to \bullet \leftarrow \bullet .
The symbol \lrcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pullback.
A pushout is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \leftarrow \bullet \to \bullet .
The symbol \ulcorner in the previous diagram denotes that the square is a pushout.
An terminal object is a limit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of limits, an object t is terminal in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism c\to t.
An initial object is a colimit of an empty diagram.
By the universal property of colimits, an object i is initial in the category C if and only if for every object c, there is a unique morphism i\to c.
An equalizer is a limit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .
A coequalizer is a colimit of a diagram of shape \bullet \rightrightarrows \bullet .

fr:title.text: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Limits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cones. Explicitly, let J\xrightarrow {d} C be a diagram and suppose x\xrightarrow {\lambda } D and y\xrightarrow {\mu } D are both limiting cones. Then there is a unique isomorphism x\to y commuting with the \lambda and \mu .
Dually, colimits are unique up to unique isomorphism of cocones.

This follows from the characterization of representable isomorphism, but we give a direct proof. To show isomorphism, note that the universal property of limits induces a pair of unique maps x\xtofrom [g]{f} y commuting with the cones; it remains to show these are isomorphisms. The composite gf is a map x\to x commuting with the cone \lambda , but 1_x is another such map, so by uniqueness of suchs maps gf = 1_x. The same works on the other side.
Let J\xrightarrow {F,G} C be naturally isomorphic diagrams. Then if their limits exist, they are isomorphic.
Taking limits is functorial and functors preserve isomorphism.
Let J be an index category and let C be J-complete. Then there is a functor C^J \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{lim}_J} C which acts on functors by taking the limit.
Note that this theorem relies on a choice of witnesses to the completeness of C, i.e. a canonical choice of limit of each J-shaped diagram.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the limits \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F and \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F exist. Then \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F exists, and the three limits are isomorphic.

Since representable isomorphism implies isomorphism, it suffices to prove that C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} F) \cong C(X, \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I F) naturally in X. Since hom functors preserve limits, the desired result becomes \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} C(X, F) \cong \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{lim}_I C(X, F); i.e., the general case reduces to that of Set. By the isomorphism I\times J\cong J\times I, it suffices to prove the first isomorphism.

The proof is essentially by currying. Let I\times J\xrightarrow {G} Set be a diagram. By the construction of limits in Set, the limit \operatorname *{lim}_J G(i, -) is the set of cones over G(i, -) with summit *, hence equivalently the set of J-tuples (x_j\in G(i, j)) satisfying G(i, f)(x_j) = x_{j'} for each j\xrightarrow {f}j'\in J. Taking the limit over I, we now conclude that \operatorname *{lim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J G consists of the tuples (x_{ij}\in G(i, j)) which commute with G-images of maps in I and J. This is exactly the data of \operatorname *{lim}_{I\times J} G.

Let I\times J\xrightarrow {F} C be a bifunctorial diagram such that the following limits and colimits exist. Then there is a canonical map \operatorname *{colim}_I \operatorname *{lim}_J F\to \operatorname *{lim}_J \operatorname *{colim}_I F.
In particular, the map goes from a colimit to a limit because colimits are easy to map out of, while limits are easy to map into.

fr:title.text: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Limits and colimits in functor categories are computed pointwise

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a small category. Then where \operatorname *{obj} C is the discrete category of objects, the forgetful functor C^A\to C^{\operatorname *{obj} A} strictly creates all limits and colimits in C. For each a\in A, the evaluation at a functor C^A\to C preserves all limits and colimits which exist in C.

We prove the result for limits and conclude for colimits by duality. For any diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C, the definition of \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D) is the set of natural transformations c\to D, which by definition is the set of cones \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c). A right adjoint \operatorname *{lim}_J to this functor is thus characterized by the natural isomorphism \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c)\cong C(c, \operatorname *{lim}_J D), which is the definition of the limit. Thus pointwise the right adjoint and the limit agree, and so the right adjoint extends uniquely to the limit functor.

Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in a locally small category C whose limit exists. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(x, \operatorname *{lim} F)\cong \operatorname *{lim} C(x, F-), where the latter is a limit in Set.
Dually, let the colimit of F exist. Then there is a natural isomorphism C(\operatorname *{colim} F, x)\cong \operatorname *{lim}_{J^\text {op}} C(F-, x).

Let C be locally small. The hom bifunctor preserves limits in both arguments. In particular, covariant hom-functors preserve limits and contravariant hom-functors preserve colimits, and so representable functors preserve limits.

We show the result for covariant hom-functors. Let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a diagram in C with limit \operatorname *{lim} F\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Fj. The image of this diagram under C(x, -) is the diagram J\xrightarrow {F} C\xrightarrow {C(x, -)} Set, which is a limit in Set by the representability of limits.

fr:title.text: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The Yoneda embedding preserves and reflects limits.
Preservation of limits follows because hom-functors preserve limits and limits in functor categories are computed pointwise.
Reflection of limits follows because the Yoneda embedding is fully faithful and fully faithful functors reflect limits.
A category is complete if it has all small limits.
A category is cocomplete if it has all small colimits.
A category is complete if and only if it has all small products and equalizers.
Dually, a category is cocomplete if and only if it has all small coproducts and coequalizers.
The forwards direction is immediate, because products and equalizers are limits.
In the backwards direction, let J\xrightarrow {F} C be a small diagram. Now we define maps c and d using the universal property of the product as follows:

To demonstrate the universal property of the limit, let z\xrightarrow {\mu } F be another cone over F. Then the legs of the cone yield a map z\to \prod _{j\in J} Fj by the universal property of the product. Since it is a cone, hence commutes with Ff, this map equalizes the previous diagram. We obtain the desired result by the universal property of the equalizer.
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
A poset is a preorder which is skeletal as a category; equivalently, this means its relation is additionally antisymmetric.
